articles.author: Igor Vorobiov
articles.description:
APIs are essential for enabling communication between software systems. Over time, several popular methods have emerged ‚Äî each with its own strengths and trade-offs. From the well-established SOAP protocol to modern approaches like GraphQL and gRPC, understanding these popular API communication styles helps developers choose the right tool for their needs. Let‚Äôs take a quick look at the five most popular ways APIs communicate today.
In short, it‚Äôs a protocol that enables developers to invoke methods on remote objects or services. It‚Äôs a pretty old dinosaur, both in terms of age and weight. It‚Äôs based on XML, which means it carries a lot of text ‚Äî much more than REST or GraphQL.
It was invented a long time ago and is known for being very secure, strict, and reliable. If you compare them lik‚Ä¶
articles.title: The 5 Most Popular Ways APIs Communicate Today

articles.author: Kris Chou
articles.description:
Over the past 5+ years, I've worked as a Tech Lead and Lead Engineer across multiple startups and enterprise projects. Naturally, I‚Äôve gone through several interview loops for leadership roles, and one question I keep encountering is:
‚ÄúHow do you approach code reviews as a tech lead?‚Äù
This question may seem tactical on the surface, but in reality, it reveals a lot about your engineering judgment, system thinking, and leadership philosophy.
Here's how I answer it, and how I actually approach code reviews in real-world teams.
1. Design Comes First
Does this solution align with our overall system architecture?


Is it scalable, extensible, and testable?


Does it follow the design principles and patterns we agreed on as a team?



A PR that passes all tests and looks clean but solves the wron‚Ä¶
articles.title: Answering the Interview Question: "How Do You Review Code as a Tech Lead?"

articles.author: EphraimX
articles.description:
Deploying applications consistently across different CI/CD tools is a skill every engineer should master. This article focuses on how to use GitLab CI/CD to deploy a full stack Docker Compose application to Koyeb, a developer-friendly PaaS.
If you‚Äôve already followed our GitHub Actions deployment guide for the same project, you‚Äôre in the right place. We won‚Äôt rehash the application structure, Dockerfiles, or Docker Compose file ‚Äî those details remain unchanged. Instead, this guide zeroes in on the CI/CD configuration differences specific to GitLab.
You‚Äôll learn how to:
Set up your .gitlab-ci.yml file for Docker Compose deployments.
Use the Koyeb CLI within GitLab runners.
Trigger deployments by pushing to the main branch.
Monitor and debug deployment from GitLab‚Äôs UI.
Prerequisites
Getting‚Ä¶
articles.title: How to Deploy a Full Stack App to Koyeb Using Docker Compose and GitLab CI/CD

articles.author: TaiKedz
articles.description:
This is perhaps not your typical "Golang vs (language)" post... I've seen it said in various places (citations lost, please roll with it) that Go is a good replacement for shell scripting. At first, I was highly skeptical - Go is a compliled, stricly typed language with more boilerplate to "Hello world" than needed in any scirpting language. But as a compiled language, it does make sense for portability, and as a properly and strictly typed language, it makes performing complex operations easier to implement... so it was worth trying out.
Several years ago when I was still a bright-eyed and busy-tailed distro-hopper, I kept on running into the same problem: "which package manager command and keyword combination do I need on this distro again??" I wrote a simple script I called Alpacka and ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Shell/Python vs Go - practical notes form a reimplementation project

articles.author: AI News
articles.description:
TL;DR: AI is about to supercharge hackers‚Äô abilities‚Äîwhat security pros are calling ‚Äúvibe hacking.‚Äù Tools like XBOW are already auto-scanning and exploiting web flaws, and purpose-built or jailbroken LLMs (think WormGPT, FraudGPT, even ChatGPT clones) can spit out malicious code with a simple prompt. As generative models get smarter, virtually anyone‚Äîeven script-kiddies‚Äîcan tell AI ‚Äúcook me up an exploit‚Äù and watch the malware roll off the assembly line.
The real worry, though, is seasoned cybercriminals using AI to scale attacks they already know inside out. What used to take days of tinkering can now be done in 30 minutes, supercharging zero-day strikes, polymorphic malware, and mass automated break-ins. While OpenAI, Anthropic, and others keep tightening guardrails (and even offer bug bounties for jailbreak hunters), the arms race is on‚Äîand the next big cyber nightmare might just be an AI prompt away.
articles.title: The Rise of ‚ÄòVibe Hacking' Is the Next AI Nightmare

articles.author: SNS-Srinivasu
articles.description:
This article walks through the complete setup and deployment of a containerized application on AWS EKS using an EC2 instance. It includes tool installation, EKS cluster creation, Docker image handling with ECR, and Kubernetes deployment.

Git-Repo: https://github.com/SNS-Srinivasu/eks-app-deployment

bash
# Install AWS CLI

curl "https://awscli.amazonaws.com/awscli-exe-linux-x86_64.zip" -o "awscliv2.zip"
unzip awscliv2.zip
sudo ./aws/install


# Install Kubectl

# Remove any existing broken kubectl
sudo rm -f /usr/local/bin/kubectl

# Download the kubectl binary (latest stable release)
curl -LO "https://dl.k8s.io/release/$(curl -Ls https://dl.k8s.io/release/stable.txt)/bin/linux/amd64/kubectl"

# Make it executable
chmod +x kubectl

# Move it to a system path
sudo mv kubectl /usr/local/bin‚Ä¶
articles.title: Deploy a Dockerized App to AWS EKS Using EC2

articles.author: GoConnect.dev
articles.description:
If you've ever had a product idea but didn‚Äôt know what to do with it, or if you've shared something online only to have it buried under algorithm noise ‚Äî you‚Äôre not alone.
We built GoConnect‚Äôs Idea Hub to fix that.
It‚Äôs a space designed for people who think, build, and care about getting real feedback ‚Äî without the noise of hype posts or social algorithms getting in the way.
The Idea Hub is a new feature on GoConnect, where you can share product ideas ‚Äî big or small ‚Äî and start conversations around them. It‚Äôs not about ‚Äúlaunching‚Äù or pitching. It‚Äôs about early-stage thinking, honest feedback, and finding collaborators.
Whether it‚Äôs:
A napkin sketch of a dev tool,
A question about a potential SaaS feature,
Or just something you‚Äôre not sure is worth building yet‚Ä¶
The Idea Hub gives you a pla‚Ä¶
articles.title: ‚ú® GoConnect's Idea Hub ‚Äî A New Place to Share and Grow Product Ideas
